awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:Research: Advancing Engineering Education Research through Peer Review Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Questions about how knowledge is socially constructed and how boundary work shapes the development of a scientific field are of central importance to the development and growth of any field. Peer review is a key site of social construction of knowledge and micropolitics of knowledge production. It serves as a gateway for new knowledge to become part of a field. As an emerging and interdisciplinary field, engineering education research presents a valuable, and timely, opportunity to learn about processes of disciplinary development, and to better understand the micropolitics of peer review in an emerging and interdisciplinary field. Moreover, in engineering education research, the boundaries of the field can have implications for insights that ultimately influence engineering education practices. As a relatively new field, it has been noted that engineering education research remains underdeveloped in some regards, including inclusion of theoretical and methodological approaches from social science fields. However, little research has been done to identify how the boundaries of the field are established and maintained. This study is the first investigation of a large group of engineering education researchers' peer review experiences and editors' perspectives. 
 	
The research objective of this project is to identify research normativities and values shaping the emerging field of engineering education research through the peer review processes. The intervention objective of this project is to develop and implement materials targeted to engineering education researchers so that they better understand their field and how it can be advanced in new directions. In-depth qualitative interviews are being conducted with 40 authors and at least 5 editors of the Journal of Engineering Education. Authors include those who have had articles published and those who have had articles rejected, as well as those who fall into both categories. The interviews explore participants' peer review experiences and beliefs about the field's boundaries. Emergent patterns in experiences and beliefs will be used to identify theoretical, methodological, epistemological, and topical normativities that shape the field. These patterns provide new insights into engineering education research, specifically, its dominant values, boundaries, and levels of interdisciplinarity, thus also providing new insights into the social construction of knowledge in an emerging, interdisciplinary field. Based on findings from the interviews, stakeholder-specific workshops are being conducted for different groups: current and future engineering education researchers. These workshops and associated materials are designed to help the engineering education research community critically reflect on and advance the field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project met its Intellectual Merit goals by advancing understandings of how knowledge is socially constructed and how boundary work shapes the development of academic disciplines. Peer review is a key site of social construction of knowledge and micropolitics of knowledge production. It serves as a gateway for new knowledge to become part of a field. As an emerging and interdisciplinary field, engineering education research presented a valuable, and timely, opportunity to learn about processes of disciplinary development, and to better understand the micropolitics of peer review in an emerging and interdisciplinary field. Moreover, in engineering education research, the boundaries of the field can have implications for insights that ultimately influence engineering education practices. Through interviews with journal authors and editors, as well as document analysis of peer reviews, this project identified research normativities and values shaping the emerging field of engineering education research through the peer review processes. These patterns provided new insights into engineering education research, specifically, its dominant values, boundaries, and levels of interdisciplinarity. By identifying engineering education research peer review normativities at this point in time, we can compare its present state to the past and determine where change has occurred and where it has not. 

 

When analyzing the peer review documentation, one of the challenges in evaluating the tone of the review was that members of the research team interpreted the tone differently. This highlighted an opportunity to facilitate a discussion within our field about what is the appropriate tone for a review. Many of our interview participants highlighted wanting to establish a constructive tone when writing a review, but not feeling the same tone when receiving reviews. Therefore, the project team extended the goals for this project to further explore review tone. This was initially scoped through a special session with engineering education researchers at the American Society for Engineering Education conference with the goal of facilitating a discussion among members of the field relating to review tone. Additionally, the researchers applied the framework of Mindset Culture previously explored by Mary Murphy and Carol Dweck to the documented reviews. Using this framework, we were able to create guidelines for promoting the growth and development of a manuscript through a review – as compared to a review that promotes a more fixed or unchangeable tone with respect to the manuscript, typically resulting in a more negative or personalized tone. Our guidelines were shared at with the broader education community at the Hawaii International Conference on Education as well as novice engineering education reviewers through the Journal of Engineering Education Mentored Reviewer Program.

 

The overall project produced 5 conference papers, 1 journal article, and 4 professional development workshops. The Conference papers were presented at the 2019 American Society for Engineering Education Annual Conference, the 2019 and 2021 Research in Engineering Education Symposium, and the 2020 and 2022 Hawaii International Conference on Education. The journal article was published in Social Epistemology in 2022. Findings were also disseminated via contributions to the 2020 Australasian Association for Engineering Education annual conference, the American Society for Engineering Education Task Force on Journals, and the Journal of Engineering Education Mentored Reviewer Program. Project dissemination efforts contributed to the fields of Science and Technology Studies, faculty development, and engineering education, thus demonstrating the interdisciplinary reach of the findings. A handout on productive peer review can be accessed at https://sociologyofengineering.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/Productive-Peer-Reviews-AAEE-Handout.pdf as well as a rubric for promoting a more growth perspective in your review available here: https://sociologyofengineering.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/07/Mindset-framework.pdf

 

Broader impacts from this project reached engineering education graduate students, engineering education researchers, faculty developers, and education graduate students. Based on findings from the interviews and document analysis, stakeholder-specific workshops were created and conducted for different groups of stakeholders: 1 for engineering education graduate students, 1 for faculty developers, and 2 for engineering education researchers. The workshops and associated materials were designed to help those communities better understand and participate in, critically reflect on, and advance their respective fields. Additionally, this project promoted teaching, training, and learning through the support of three graduate students from the College of Education at Penn State who worked on the project. These students co-authored conference papers and a journal article.
